item.title: Construction Firm Accused in India Overpass Collapse
item.description: The police in Kolkata detained eight executives of the company that built the elevated highway, after at least 23 people died.
item.dc:creator: HARI KUMAR, GEETA ANAND and NIDA NAJAR
item.media:description: Relatives mourned a victim of the overpass collapse on Friday, a day after the disaster in Kolkata killed at least 23.

item.title: Hamas Releases Photographs Said to Show Captured Israelis
item.description: The militant group also made public images of two Israeli soldiers killed in 2014.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Angela Merkel’s Unpopular Goodness
item.description: Germany faces a new reality, with terror elsewhere in Europe and the refugee crisis at its doors.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: DANIEL KEHLMANN

item.title: View From Space Hints at a New Viking Site in North America
item.description: The site was identified last summer after satellite images showed possible man-made shapes under discolored vegetation on the Newfoundland coast.
item.dc:creator: RALPH BLUMENTHAL
item.media:description: Douglas Bolender, left, and Sarah H. Parcak, right, looking for evidence of a Viking presence at a remote site, called Point Rosee by researchers, in Newfoundland. If confirmed, the site would be the second known Viking settlement in North America.

item.title: Obama Rebukes Donald Trump’s Comments on Nuclear Weapons
item.description: The president questioned Mr. Trump’s fitness for office in comments made after a meeting of more than 50 world leaders to discuss nuclear security.
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER
item.media:description: President Obama with Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan at the Nuclear Security Summit on Friday in Washington.

item.title: A Yoga Master, the King of ‘Baba Cool,’ Stretches Out an Empire
item.description: Baba Ramdev has emerged as the leader of the “Baba Cool Movement” — a group of spiritual men who are marketing health-based products based on the ancient Indian medicinal system.
item.dc:creator: GEETA ANAND
item.media:credit: Kuni Takahashi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Baba Ramdev, 50, a yoga teacher, business owner and anti-corruption activist, leading students at his ashram in Haridwar, India, in February.

item.title: Bela Biszku, Hungarian Official Tried in 1956 Uprising, Dies at 94
item.description: Mr. Biszku, who denied wrongdoing, was appealing a convicted on charges related to repression after the 1956 Hungarian uprising.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.media:description: Bela Biszku arriving at trial in Budapest in March 2014 after being charged with war crimes.

item.title: Somali Militant Leader Believed Killed in Drone Strike
item.description: Hassan Ali Dhoore, considered an important member of the Shabab security and intelligence wing, had been under U.S. surveillance for some time.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: HELENE COOPER

item.title: Amid Clashes, Greece Presses On With Plan to Deport Migrants
item.description: Several refugees were hospitalized after hundreds broke out of a detention center to protest a European Union deal allowing Greece to send refugees back to Turkey.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: LIZ ALDERMAN and KAREEM FAHIM
item.media:description: Hundreds of migrants broke out of an overcrowded detention center Friday on the Greek island of Chios.

item.title: Libya’s U.N.-Backed Government Ventures Farther Into Tripoli
item.description: The unity government, which landed by boat on Wednesday, appears to be getting some support from other factions.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH

item.title: Jacob Zuma Says He’ll Repay South Africa for Home Improvements
item.description: Mr. Zuma said that the upgrade of his private home had caused “frustration and confusion,” but that he never meant to subvert the Constitution.
item.dc:creator: NORIMITSU ONISHI

item.title: Turkey Has Forcibly Returned Thousands of Refugees to Syria, Amnesty International Says
item.description: The report exposes the perils of a deal reached last month that allows Greece to send migrants back to Turkey, and reflects shifting attitudes toward refugees in the countries bordering Syria.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: Saudis Moving to Reduce Dependence on Oil Money
item.description: A top Saudi prince has announced new elements of a plan to restructure the country’s economy, which is reeling amid a drop in world prices.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD and STANLEY REED
item.media:description: As the head of a council that oversees Saudi economic policy, Prince Mohammed bin Salman is leading the kingdom’s search for ways to reduce the country’s dependence on oil income.

item.title: New Ebola Case Confirmed in Liberia; Guinea Tries a Vaccine
item.description: Although the World Health Organization no longer considers Ebola an international emergency, new cases in Liberia and Guinea show the disease’s resilience.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: A health worker took a blood sample from a man who was suspected of having Ebola at a hospital in Foya, Liberia, in December 2014.

item.title: Brussels Airport’s Reopening Delayed by Security Dispute
item.description: The airport was closed Friday, and it was unclear whether it would be able to open on Saturday morning, an airport spokeswoman said.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN
item.media:description: Tentlike structures have been erected outside Brussels Airport for possible use as temporary passenger check-in areas.

item.title: Chinese Phrase Adds Mystery to Anbang’s About-Face on Starwood
item.description: A vague Chinese regulation allows insurance companies to make overseas investments of less than 15 percent of their assets, but it has wiggle room.
item.dc:creator: KEITH BRADSHER
item.media:description: Wu Xiaohui, chairman of the Anbang Insurance Group, which recently dropped its bid to buy Starwood Hotels and Resorts.

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: The Dirty Old Men of Pakistan
item.description: They don’t want to beat up their wives. They just want to make sure they have the right to do so.
item.dc:creator: MOHAMMED HANIF
item.media:description: Memoona, the victim of an acid attack in a family feud, in Karachi, Pakistan, in 2011.

item.title: Artist Says Brazilian Protesters Copied His Giant Rubber Duck
item.description: The duck displayed in Brazil bears too much of a resemblance to a six story-tall one created by the Dutch artist Florentijn Hofman, his team said.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTOPHER MELE
item.media:description: An enormous rubber duck at a protest in São Paulo, Brazil, in March, where demonstrators called for the impeachment of President Dilma Rousseff.

item.title: A C.I.A. Grunt’s Tale of the Fog of Secret War
item.description: The collective weight of all post-9/11 C.I.A. memoirs could collapse a bookshelf, but Douglas Laux brings a raw perspective to the canon.
item.dc:creator: MARK MAZZETTI
item.media:credit: T.J. Kirkpatrick for The New York Times
item.media:description: Douglas Laux served for eight years as an undercover case officer and soldier in the C.I.A.’s shadowy conflicts overseas.

item.title: Second Lion Killed in Kenya in 2 Days Reignites Outrage
item.description: A 2½-year-old lion known as Lemek was found killed by a spear one day after rangers shot another lion that confronted a crowd.
item.dc:creator: LIAM STACK
